{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3648860,"name":"","username":"digitsofpi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/digitsofpi/{size}/251110_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T16:51:16.633Z","cooked":"

Hey! I’m an incoming junior interested in CAD, but I need a decent laptop to do it. Right now, I’m running Inventor on my grandma’s old laptop that I’m pretty sure is older than me, and it’s really slow and just not practical. I have a budget of up to $800-ish, and I’d like to get a laptop that will hopefully last me through college. My team uses Inventor, it’d be nice to have something relatively portable, and I’d use it for just CAD and school stuff (like Google docs or whatever). There was some great recommendations in this recent thread but I don’t know anything much about computers so I wanted some more specific advice. Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T16:51:43.324Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":251,"reads":781,"readers_count":780,"score":1421.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/design-computers/502678","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Design Computers?","clicks":34}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70774,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3648885,"name":"Titus Casas ","username":"MrFuzzypants948","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrfuzzypants948/{size}/262988_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T16:57:37.812Z","cooked":"

You want a decent GPU which is for graphics and rendering 3e workspaces, you want a good cpu for CAD and stimulations amd calculations. For cad touchscreen isn’t really necessary and you need to buy a mouse. You would want a i7 or i9 processor or AMD equivalent. Any recent GPU is good, as long as it is not integrated graphics. ACER makes very good laptops and dell and lenovo ones are also good, but acer is the best in that budget range

So like I said in that thread, my friend just picked up one of these and it is really nice and would work well for CAD. And it is well within your budget.
HP Victus

truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T18:10:32.719Z","cooked":"

an important criterion that isn’t usually mentioned in laptop specs is thermal power. it’s cool to be able to boost the CPU to 4.4 ghz, and Fusion will definitely do that sometimes, but if you don’t have good cooling, then you won’t be able to sustain this speed for long. the nice slick victus design has no obvious air handling, so I would expect it to be thermally throttled most of the time.

unfortunately most laptops that pay specific attention to this issue are ridiculously expensive gaming laptops.

I’ve had good luck with used equipment from backmarket. Here’s an example of what you can get for $800. Every day has a wide variety of computers of different ages.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T18:55:28.158Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":530,"readers_count":529,"score":181.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.backmarket.com/en-us/p/dell-g5-5590-156-inch-core-i7-9750h-16gb-256gb-nvidia-geforce-gtx-1660-ti-intel-uhd-graphics-630-qwerty-english-us/1fa63da2-35f9-4cdc-a92d-97861106a92b","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":34},{"url":"https://backmarket.com","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Refurbished tech that's better for the planet | Back Market","clicks":13}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649051,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T19:14:33.251Z","cooked":"

I would look to the used market

“Interested in CAD” and "trying to become a professional " are going to be different things.

My take: you shouldn’t worry about the simulation stuff and the computer that involves (e.g. large GPU/ large CPU) unless that is your primary interest. If you are going to college for this stuff they will have machines with more horsepower to tackle that stuff by the time you get to those projects/classes. If this is your everyday laptop I would focus on a good mix of portability, reasonable power/thermals, and a screen that isn’t garbage. (To hit these targets probably looking at the used market). You will also want a half decent mouse as well (nothing crazy, but a few extra buttons and a good scroll wheel really helps), so that may hit your budget or be an “upgrade soon” item.

You also need to ask the question of where cloud based (onshape) fits into your desired CAD education, as the above advice changes if you are not running as much stuff in your machine.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T19:17:25.327Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":514,"readers_count":513,"score":272.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/7","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649055,"name":"Mike Schreiber","username":"Mike_Schreiber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_schreiber/{size}/200098_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T19:16:45.648Z","cooked":"

CAD is generally single core CPU performance limited. Spending more money on more CPU cores doesn’t get you much CAD performance. 6 cores is probably plenty, 8 would be a reasonable splurge, but doesn’t really help with CAD. Comparing CPUs / clock speeds across generations isn’t easy and you need to rely on single core benchmark data.

You need a decent enough GPU to open / spin around larger models, but you don’t actually need anything that fancy, GPUs have come a long way in the past 5 years where most dedicated laptop GPUs can pretty much just handle CAD. You probably want to avoid integrated graphics.

Get 32 GB of RAM. You won’t be happy with 16, and you won’t probably won’t need much more (and also won’t find reasonably priced laptops with much more).

Storage size is a personal choice, but I wouldn’t consider less than 512 GB.

I like a 15-16" laptop if I’m going to be CADing, otherwise you lose to much real estate to menus, you can also consider a smaller laptop and use an external / second monitor.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T19:16:45.648Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":451,"readers_count":450,"score":305.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"Mike Schreiber","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7123,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649101,"name":"Isaac Proctor","username":"Isaac-The-Pro","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/isaac-the-pro/{size}/265401_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T20:14:51.165Z","cooked":"

get a base model m4 macbook air. Great battery life, great touchpad(but still get a mouse), and should work fine for CAD(but macos doesn’t natively support inventor, so either use boot camp or switch to onshape or fusion which you should probably do anyway). Also if you need more than 256gb, get an external ssd cuz apple overcharges for more storage

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T20:15:26.615Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":390,"readers_count":389,"score":163.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"Isaac Proctor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69147,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6352 Scouting/Design Lead"},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/9","custom_user_title":"6352 Scouting/Design Lead","reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649138,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T20:51:18.681Z","cooked":"

counterpoint: i spend a *lot* of time with fusion 360 on a machine with an 11th gen i7, using intel iris xe (integrated) graphics on a 14 inch screen, with 16 gb of ram, and it works fine. there are times, with giant assemblies, where it chokes a bit, but that doesn’t happen very often. i do sometimes wish for a larger screen, but not that often: it’s nice to be able to carry this thing around everywhere.

also, it’s convenient to be able to use a single machine for everything, including the driver station. i’m not sure if the driver station will be windows-only in 2027, but it certainly is for 2026.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T20:51:18.681Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":383,"readers_count":382,"score":171.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7123,"username":"Mike_Schreiber","name":"Mike Schreiber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_schreiber/{size}/200098_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649181,"name":"Sam","username":"clydefrog88","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/clydefrog88/{size}/150683_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T21:20:15.893Z","cooked":"

A “powerful” laptop is overrated. Battery life, chassis quality, screen quality, and weight are the only metrics that matter to me any more. Anything that doesn’t thermally throttle isn’t truly portable. I’ve had 17" workstations. I’d rather have an ultrabook and remote into hardware as needed.

I often leave my ipad at home and bring only my MBA 13 on trips.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T21:24:12.258Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":362,"readers_count":361,"score":142.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"Sam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7309,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649307,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-08T23:47:19.368Z","cooked":"

Basically all of this.

Disable HT of you really only CAD on it.

I got a 17in laptop with 4k screen for CAD and it is nice to have the extra real estate.

Keep an eye on slickdeals.net for something in your price range that meets your minimum requirements. Refurb, open box, and other specials come up regularly and you can save a bundle with a little patience.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-08T23:47:19.368Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":340,"readers_count":339,"score":128.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"http://slickdeals.net","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":27}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7123,"username":"Mike_Schreiber","name":"Mike Schreiber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_schreiber/{size}/200098_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649325,"name":"Harry C","username":"Hazzer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hazzer/{size}/258951_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T00:57:21.744Z","cooked":"

About halfway through my undergraduate I’ve gotten a ThinkPad T14s from an auction site. What I learned from that experience is that A) ThinkPad laptops are awesome, and B) Refurbished/Secondhand is almost always the way to go.

I find it easy to “get lost in the sauce” but my truth is you don’t need a crazy high end GPU + CPU. My ThinkPad is still my daily driver and I love it to bits. If I was in your shoes again, I’d only be looking for more RAM (maybe more battery life).
Inventor is still my preferred CAD software and I can run it fine.

We keep a voluntary list of our laptops with a couple of notes if you’re interested too:

docs.google.com

Laptops that 4788 has

This Sheet is private

As an aside I love how this thread is seemingly nuculating around “quality second hand is the play here”

Added bonus of the second hand market: you have all of the reviews and real world experience of folks at your disposal, you shouldn’t run into many surprises and know where the strength / weaknesses of different products are.

clydefrog88:

I’d rather have an ultrabook and remote into hardware as needed

My use case is different than most mechanical engineers, but this is absolutely what I have discovered over the past 10 years or so.

Just make sure there is enough RAM… Web browsers for enhanced terminals/environments can get hungry.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T01:39:36.875Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":295,"readers_count":294,"score":109.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/14","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649336,"name":"Titus Casas ","username":"MrFuzzypants948","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrfuzzypants948/{size}/262988_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T01:56:36.123Z","cooked":"

In the end it boils down to what you want it for, because docs and basic CAD isn’t very demanding, but if you ever want to game with it or do local CAD stimulations, then you’ll need those high specs like good cpu and gpu

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T01:57:04.018Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":273,"readers_count":272,"score":54.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"Titus Casas ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74940,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649517,"name":"Ian Osborn","username":"Sands","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T13:03:13.426Z","cooked":"

From a reliability perspective, HP would be my recommendation. I work at a blue chip medical device company, they chose HP largely because of that, or so I’m told. Same with two prior employers.

The standard issue engineering laptop (with a dedicated graphics card) is a HP Z Book.

Ebay has them for around $900-1200 or so. A substantial discount from MSRP.

My personal laptop is around 8 years old or so. HP Zbook with a P1000 (?) card. Runs CAD just fine. My work laptop, again a HP Z Book with a A2000 card.

The HP “corporate” laptops have aluminum cases and have been quite robust. ZBooks and EliteBooks.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":59,"updated_at":"2025-06-09T13:03:58.308Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":260,"readers_count":259,"score":62.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502948,"topic_slug":"cad-college-laptop-advice","display_username":"Ian Osborn","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52040,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cad-college-laptop-advice/502948/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"question","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3649563,"name":"David Kravets","username":"dak000","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-09T14:37:39.524Z","cooked":"

Lot’s of great technical information in this thread, here’s my personal rec of what I use as my mentor laptop for our teams software/cam/3dp/drive laptop/Onshape. Personally I’m happy buying new, it’s a better way to guarantee the laptop and battery are in good shape, but of course that comes at a cost.

ASUS Vivobook S 16 2.8K OLED AI Laptop, Intel Core Ultra 9 285H, 16GB RAM, 1TB SSD, Backlit Keyboard, Windows 11 Home | Staples?

Pros of this laptop:
Really incredible screen, battery life is great, and it’s ultra portable. I value the quality of the keyboard/screen/overall build quality more than I value things like outright performance.

Downsides:
No dedicated graphics processor means you’ll be leaving some performance on the table for graphics. This hasn’t made a difference for me in onshape, but depending on how much simulation you may get into, you may need to look at beefier option (which usually come with the downside of worse battery, higher cost and less portability.)

16gb of ram may be too little for you… depending on how much you like opening chrome tabs

Edit: If you have a local microcenter, here’s an incredible deal on a really similar laptop (with an admittedly worse screen) but with 32gb of ram (Which I highly recommend) ASUS Vivobook 16 F1605VA-MH96 16" Laptop Computer - Indie Black; Intel Core i9 13th Gen 13900H 1.9GHz Processor; 32GB - Micro Center

Adding to the recommendations for a secondhand laptop. Many manufacturers (Dell, HP, etc.) have series of “business-class” laptops (Latitude, EliteBook, etc.), which are more expensive than their consumer-grade models, but have higher build quality and are more repairable. Businesses will buy hundreds of these, then replace them a few years later as they keep up to date. These (often gently-)used laptops can be purchased for a fraction of their original price from ebay or specialized websites. (All of team 3494’s laptops are used Dell Latitudes from our local university’s surplus store. My current laptop is an HP EliteBook from ebay.)

Here’s a post with manufactures/series of business-class laptops.

Boot camp no longer exists on ARM Macs(all M series Macs), and Macs are a bit overpriced while being hard to repair/upgrade. Also, IMO 256gb is not enough for any computer as it fills up quickly and external drives should really mostly be used for backups. For CAD, I just got an upgradeable AMD ThinkPad and called it a day.
